Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 04:56AM cathmg wrote: Hi Nancy, There is no "correct" way to do cancer-anything you are thinking or feeling is normal. When first diagnosed, I had times of positive "I can do this" thoughts, as well as times of being terrified. The trauma to the family is deep. Make sure your daughter's school knows what is going on. I had very little energy for my kids, a deep depression,  and not much family support other than my husband, and my kids have made it through to the other side. My daughter is a freshman in college, and enjoying her first year at a challenging school. My son is at the top of his class and is going for his driving test next week.   I think I have been a role model for my kids should they ever experience a serious life setback or illness-I worked really hard at getting what I needed, put myself first, and made it through to the other side. My very best wishes for you and your family, Cat
Posts.Title: I can be positive until... BioAdoptMom3 julie75

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 01:03PM cathmg wrote: Mdg and Nancy, I forgot to add that I definitely signed up for better living through chemistry and took an antidepressant and antianxiety medication for about 18 months during the worst of it. They worked great for me, and I have been able to go off them. Don't be afraid to take that XAnax! CAt
Posts.Title: I can be positive until... BioAdoptMom3 julie75

Posts.Content: May 1, 2011 11:08AM cathmg wrote: Hi Amy, I saw your first thread had some valuable responses...hope you will reconsider how you think about the site. I didn't find this site until a year after my diagnosis (was staying away from the internet), and now I check in regularly and find humor, inspiration, comfort, and valuable information here. A lot of my threads only had a few responses, but I try to let that go. Lots of times I ask myself-what can I offer here? Perhaps encouragement to a new person, or info from my onc., and I respond as I feel moved. Best wishes, Cat
Posts.Title: very surprised at how unhelpful this site is amylynn1108 Moderators

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2010 08:52AM cathmg wrote: Hi Shelley, I've had pins and needles type neuropathy in my hands a YEAR and a half out from Taxotere. It happens usually when there is a cool breeze blowing over them. It has gotten a little better.I had it during treatment and then it went away for a long time. I would be interested in hearing from other ladies, too, who have had neuropathy far out from chemo. I hope your foot numbness resolves soon! Catherine
Posts.Title: Taxotere Neuropathy - When did you get it? shells43 vnelson

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2010 01:28PM cathmg wrote: Hi, something like this did happen to me-I had 9 nodes taken out, all clear of cancer. When I asked why, my onc said they probably all lit up with the dye that shows where the lymph drains from the section of the breast where the tumor is-so they took them all as sentinel nodes. I type/use my hands all day for work, and am very active and work out. I have had no problems with lymphedema, and wish you the same. This is a very tough road, but it does get easier. Catherine
Posts.Title: Totally confused about sentinel node biopsy results LtotheK LtotheK

Posts.Content: May 11, 2010 07:14AM cathmg wrote: Hi barbe1958, First off, sorry you had that dream to start your day. I think we process pieces of this experience in dreams, for sure. My dreams, when they include my breasts, always have the "new" ones in them. Usually I'm a little self conscious because they're "fake," and I'm explaining that to people.  The general sense in my dreams is one of acceptance, though. Years ago, when my hs senior was 4, I had a vivid dream that I had breast cancer. I woke up crying. I wonder if the changes that led to the cancer were taking place then...strange. Have a healthy day !!
Posts.Title: When you dream, do you have breasts or not? barbe1958 barbe1958

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 03:49PM cathmg wrote: Hi Barb, Thanks for posting about PTSD-I don't think it's talked about enough, IMO. It has been over 2 years since diagnosis for me, and I still am going through feelings of PTSD_fear, anxiety, horror, regret...not all the time, but things can set me off, like seeing a photo of myself pre-breastcancer. Sometimes when I'm talking about growing older/retirement, etc. there's a little voice in my head that says, "if you live that long."  We recently almost put our house on the market and to move to  another house, not even another town, just another house, and I had a little breakdown. It brought up intense fear and uncertainty, which is related to the PTSD. Change is hard for me to handle-I've recently been offered a better job with more responsibility, and I'm really afraid of the change. Best wishes for our serenity and healing, Cat
Posts.Title: Emotional Issues From BC PTSD? Shanagirl SpunkyGirl

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2010 10:19AM cathmg wrote: Hi, my onc said the same thing: no scans because of stage 2. And the tumor I had was quite a bit bigger than yours. He said if I had any symptoms, then we would test at that point. I had a chest XRAY before the mastectomy, but only bloodwork since then. My onc also stopped measuring tumor markers after my 3rd visit to him. Just passed 2 years... Best wishes, Catherine
Posts.Title: Stage II - No scans?? SunnyCoconut Tabatha00

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2010 02:49PM cathmg wrote: Dear Karen, I'm sorry you've had to join "the club" noone wants to be part of-this is an excellent site for information and support. I only discovered it after all my treatment... The biopsy should be able to tell you if the cancer started in the breast ducts (ductal carcinoma) or in the lobules (lobular cancer). These are the two most common types of breast cancer. Other information will (like hormone receptor status) will determine your choices for treatment. This is tough stuff-saying a prayer for you-remember, we've all been there and made it through. You will too. Catherine
Posts.Title: invasive mammary carcinoma kira1234 kira1234

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2010 09:29PM cathmg wrote: I saw ads for it, and was spared the decision to watch or not, since we don't have showtime. My initial reaction is , great, now we're going to be shown how to "do cancer," and how we should present ourselves. I can't imagine that the darkest moments of a cancer diagnosis and treatment will be shown-think taking off a mastectomy bandage for the first time, or telling your children you have cancer and hearing them scream and cry. I don't think a show would be done about a man  and his prostate cancer.  This doesn't sit well with me!
Posts.Title: Showtime "Big C" SusieMTN SusieMTN

Posts.Content: May 24, 2010 07:42PM cathmg wrote: Hi RegulJ, I never lost my nails with TC, but had the sore nail beds and ridges in the nail. After chemo I kept them short and clipped them often to get the ridges grown out-took a couple months. Good luck and they will return to normal! Catherine
Posts.Title: Taxotere and funky finger nails RegulJ cathmg

Posts.Content: May 27, 2010 09:54PM cathmg wrote: Hi Rachel1, So sorry to hear you are facing breast cancer, but I'm glad you found this site-it is full of information and the wonderful people here are great support. I think most people here would say they felt the same extreme fear-it is totally understandable. I was almost unable to function when first diagnosed-to some meds for anxiety for awhile that helped some. Know that so many women have walked this path and you WILL get through. For now-take someone with you for support and note taking at your medical appointments. Search this site for information re. your type and stage of cancer. Have you met with your oncologist yet? Sending you a hug- Catherine
Posts.Title: Please help Rachel1 mawhinney

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2010 05:02PM cathmg wrote: Dear Gutsy, I am sorry to hear that you have had to join this club-it is normal to feel fearful and overwhelmed-we have all been there, and it is so hard, especially at diagnosis. I didn't even want to know numbers or read my pathology report at first, so I know where you're coming from. I still haven't read that report! Don't worry about that whole "positive attitude" line-your feelings are normal. Do you have a support person who can go to your appointments with you, to take notes? Many women have walked this road-you are NOT alone, Catherine

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2011 08:31AM cathmg wrote: Hello dreidteacher, Sorry you have reason to be on these boards, but they are a great support and comfort. I hope your biopsy is benign, and that the waiting isn't too hard on you. Cat.

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2011 04:36PM cathmg wrote: Hi geogal, I was initially scheduled for a lumpectomy on R breast, but the MRI showed multifocal disease, and  I needed a mastectomy. At that time I said take them both off-the left prophylactically. I didn't want to do the constant screening. It was very much a "gut" decision. Also, I knew of 2 women who developed cancer in their "good" breast after breast cancer on the other side. Tough decision-best wishes to you. Cat

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2011 08:45PM cathmg wrote: I haven't been through the exact same symptoms that you had, but I did have an incident at work where I felt dizzy (heart murmur) and then became convinced that I was going to pass out and have to be taken to the hospital, and then OF COURSE they would do an MRI or some such test and find mets. I ended up have a slight panic attack, going home, and popping an ativan while I lay on the couch. Yes, FUN days indeed!!!
Posts.Title: When Headache Turns Panic Attack BrandyB vivvygirl

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2010 08:35PM cathmg wrote: Hi, hope our replies will give you some peace of mind. My onc didn't do any pre or post surgery tests for metastasis, other than a chest Xray before surgery. He says no testing unless I have symptoms, and the cancer I had is further along than yours. I also waited over a week for pathology results, but not more than 2 weeks. Best wishes-this is a great site for support and info. Cathmg

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2011 03:36PM cathmg wrote: I am so sorry. Thank you for sharing this lovely picture-you can see her warm spirit in her eyes. Wishing you and your family peace.
Posts.Title: Olga Simkin Z"L leprechaun Bestbird

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2011 04:43PM cathmg wrote: Hi PatriceRose, I am sorry to meet you on this site, but I hope it will bring you as much comfort as it has brought me. I hear you about the curve ball of learning that you may need a mastectomy. My initial ultrasound (mammo didn't pick anything up) showed stage 1, small tumor-lumpectomy was the plan. After the MRI I got a call from the surgeon-sorry, BIG tumor, no way to save the breast, and no longer stage 1. I had a little break down that day. Cancer sucks, and all the jabbing, tests, and waiting do ,too. Just take it one day at a time-a minute at a time if you have to. Now I find myself going on 3 years since diagnosis, and life has resumed a normal (pretty normal) pattern. You will get there, too. Catherine
Posts.Title: Core Biopsy of 2 different quadrants PatriceRose dlb823

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2011 07:11PM cathmg wrote: Oh, StephB, I'm so sorry you had to go through a biopsy. And I can relate to the humiliation you are feeling-I never liked my small yet saggy boobs, and I found myself having to bare them and be poked and prodded by a small army of strangers.  I hope you got benign results, but if it's anything, we are here to hold your hand. Cat
